turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Number 96-126, Walker Chandler v. Zell D. Miller, Governor of Georgia.
Mr. Chandler.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
In 1990 the State of Georgia adopted a law requiring drug testing of all members of the State government, State employees.
Almost as an afterthought, it adopted a law requiring drug testing as a condition of employment or candidacy for candidates for public office.
The first of those laws was struck down in the lower courts.
This law was brought forward before this Court by me and my co-plaintiff, who ran for office in 1994.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Chandler--

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --you say that the petitioners ran for office in '94, and in the petition you brought here there's no assertion that any of the petitioners plan to run again in the future, is there?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Not in the... as I recall, not in the actual pleadings in the lower court.
However--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: No.
So how would we have jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Your Honor, I believe this case would not be moot, because it would be capable of repetition and yet evading--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, how would it be if none of the petitioners plan to run again?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Your Honor, I plan to run again.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But that was not stated--

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: That was not stated below.

Also, Justice O'Connor, I... my candidacy and the candidacy of all Libertarian Party members is premised on the concepts of limited government and freedom from unconstitutional searches and seizures among all the other liberties reserved to the people by the Founding Fathers, and in that respect I would think that OCGA 21-2-140 is violative of the interests of all candidates, whether or not--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Well, that's a merits argument, certainly, but normally we would look to see if there's some situation in a case like this of being capable of repetition and avoiding any review, and normally we would look to see some avowal that yes, indeed, these petitioners or at least one of them intends to run again.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Yes, I understand that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And you didn't seek to bring this on behalf of a class of candidates.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: No, sir, Your Honor, I did not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Chandler--

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --I'm wondering why, if you want to raise this issue, you don't have to refuse to take the drug test, rather than go ahead and take it and get on the ballot and then challenge it later.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Your Honor, we filed this action prior to submitting to the test, prior to qualification by having this little piece of paper that certified us as being drug-free.
We were the nominees of our party.

We had an obligation to take forward the message of our party, the other messages of our party in the electoral process, so we essentially had no choice but to submit... unwillingly, perhaps, but to submit to this State-ordered search.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When did you file the suit, before the election or after the election?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Before the election, Your Honor, in May of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So at that time there's no doubt that the case was not moot.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: At that time it was very much alive.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So the complaint is that you... what, that you didn't amend your complaint in order to assert repetition after the election?
Have we ever required that, amending a complaint in a suit that originally was not moot in order to aver that mootness has not occurred?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I don't know, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't recall we've ever required that.
Anyway, as an officer of the court, you represent to us that you intend to run again, that this issue will arise again if the Georgia law stands?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

We search in vain the cases that this Court has handed down which deal with suspicionless searches to find where any blanket search of this nature, this magnitude, and lacking any showing of any compelling State interest, has been granted by this Court.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Suppose that a State agency said, in the interests of all of our employees, everyone once a year must take a physical exam.
We don't want to know the results.
All we want you to do is to say that you've gone to a doctor, any doctor you want, for a physical examination.
Is that a search?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I would think that would be a search.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: When does a search arise, when you go into the doctor's office?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I would think so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Even though the results are disclosed only to you?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I would think that it would be a search, because if the result of that search is that you can no longer serve in that agency, then--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, no.
No, the agency says, we don't care what the medical exam discloses.
We just, in the interests of our employees we want you to be examined once a year.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Well, I would think, Your Honor, that's... with all due respect, that's not before the Court, and... but the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, there are a lot of things that are not before the Court that are going to be before the Court based on this opinion, and so we have to write an opinion that covers more than your particular case because we're interested in the general principle.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So I'm asking why this is a search.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --I would think that it would be a search if, as a result of that search, a person could lose employment.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's not my hypothetical.
All you have to do is go to the doctor and just certify that you've had a physical exam once a year at a doctor of your choice.
The agency says we want to do this in the interests of our employees, and that may well... we can play with the hypothetical.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The agency pays for it, or whatever.
Why is that a search?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I would think it would be a search under the principles of... that were announced in Schermberger, which drew a distinction between bodily searches--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That is to say, Schmerber?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, there the... involuntarily a needle was inserted in the... with the patient by a doctor who was not of his choice at a time that was not of his choice.
He had... he was there, on the gurney, in custody.
But that's quite different, it seems to me, from just saying go to a doctor once a year.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: It may well be, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It may well be?
You think... I assume this physical exam requires a strip, right?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And you're saying that that's not a search, requiring you to go to somebody else and strip down and have that person examine your body?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I think it's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What possibly could be a search if that's not a search?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, you might want to argue about whether it's an unreasonable search, but you don't have any doubt it's a search, do you?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: No, sir, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Chandler, would you have any problem if what the State did instead of requiring a drug test within 30 days of filing your nominating petition is require every candidate for the State office to file an affidavit certifying that the candidate is not now and has not in the past used or ingested illegal narcotic drugs?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I would object to that, Your Honor, because that would--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: There's no search.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --There is no search, but I--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: It certainly wouldn't... you wouldn't be here on the basis that you are here today.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --That would be true.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And a State has wide latitude, does it not, to define qualifications for State office?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, so long as those... so long as they do not violate people's constitutional protections.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And what constitutional protection would be violated by requiring such an affidavit, that to be a candidate for State office you certify that you're not a drug abuser?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Or never have been in your hypothetical, Your Honor.
You asked if I would object, and I would object not on a constitutional grounds--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I'm asking on what constitutional basis.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --I'm sorry, Your Honor, I fail to know of a constitutional basis that that might fit within that hypothetical.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You just wouldn't like it.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I think that it might have some implication for free... free speech implications under the First Amendment, Your Honor, but--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, if you had to take an oath that you have never been disloyal to the Government of the United States, of a State, or you've never been a member of, say, the Socialist Party, then you might have an objection under a different amendment than the one you're claiming, but you are claiming the Fourth Amendment, and you are doing it in relation to a bodily intrusion.
The Fourth Amendment puts on the same line as the security of one's person the security of one's papers.
Would you then question the requirement that if you run for office you must do a complete financial disclosure which will involve disclosing papers?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --I think that there the Court has drawn distinctions in the past between bodily searches and financial disclosure.
I did not object in this case to financial disclosure.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the Fourth Amendment does say persons, houses, papers, so why would you say that it's all right to demand papers but not have anything to do with the person?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Because I think there is a strong, compelling privacy interest in the person that goes far beyond the compelling... any compelling interest--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Where do you get that from in the Constitution?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Justice Ginsburg, I do not know.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, isn't--

--And is it the personal interest in not having to strip and have needles inserted, or is it the personal interest in not disclosing the results, because if it's the latter, then your case is perhaps more difficult.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I think it's the former, Your Honor.
It's the actual giving up of bodily fluids, the insertion of--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So you think most people would think that that's more of an invasion of privacy, just going to the doctor once a year, than having to disclose all of your financial records, all of your holding, all of your poverty or all of your wealth, as the case may be?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --There is a big distinction in this case, Your Honor, and that is that if I disclose my wealth I cannot be kept off the ballot.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Chandler, every invasion of privacy is not a search, is it?
Are you willing to equate every invasion of privacy with a search?

I mean, would you consider it a search if, instead of having someone examine you physically to decide whether you have cocaine in your body, you are required to disclose whether you have cocaine in your body?
I mean, that may be an invasion of privacy, but is it a search?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes sir, I would deem it a search.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You think it's a search?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So when I ask you, you know, are you a drug addict, I'm searching you?
Words have no meaning if we're going to talk like that.
Why--
--You just told me it wasn't, so which answer are you giving?
You answered to me that no, it wouldn't be a Fourth Amendment search, but I'd object, and now you tell Justice Scalia, yes, it's a search.
Now, which answer do you want to abide by here.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I'm sorry, Justice O'Connor, I'm not exactly sure of the contradiction that I've voiced here.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Mr. Chandler, going back to Justice Ginsburg's question, assuming that you had actually to disclose papers, produce papers as distinct simply from producing information, so that there really were... in the same sense that we're talking with here, there really were a search involved, I take it that your answer would... I take it that your answer to the question would not necessarily be the same as your position here, because the governmental interests involved are different.

You might or might not think the Government had a sufficient interest in requiring that kind of production from its political candidates, but at least the Government's justification, what we would look to to decide whether it was reasonable or not would, I take it, in your view be different from the weight of the government's justification in this case.
Is that a fair way to characterize your position?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I think that would be a fair way to characterize it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And your real argument before us, I take it, doesn't go to the scope of what is or is not a search, but the scope of what is permissible on the grounds that the government does have a justification which is sufficiently weighty to make that search a reasonable one.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Well, I certainly felt like it was a... that a financial search or a financial disclosure was a more reasonable government requirement than a drug test.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right, and what is your reason for saying that this particular search is not a reasonable one?
What's the nub of your attack on the government's justification?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: First, there is no real evidence of a real problem.

There... this... the searches which have been allowed by this Court have always been narrowly limited to certain areas... the front line in the war on drugs, drug interdiction, the use of firearms, the train accidents, things where a real problem or a real potentiality has been shown, and not mere hypotheticals.
And so the essence of this case is that this is just yet another attempt at expansion of governmental power over people for a very symbolic purpose, which is put on the State of Georgia.
It's not a test that's designed to keep drug abusers out of office.
It's a blanket search, carried out for symbolic purposes to... in my opinion to show that the General Assembly of Georgia is against drugs.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Chandler, at the outset of your argument you mentioned that there was a... the statute originally applied to all State employees, and that that was held invalid.
Was that by Georgia courts or a Federal court?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Federal court, but that was a companion statute, not this statute.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand, but who held it unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: The district court in Atlanta.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: A State district court, or a Federal district court?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: A Federal district court, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Was that case appealed?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I don't know, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: When was that?
Is it--

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: That was in 1990.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: This... a very similar case was brought in the district court.

this district... Harmon v. Thornburgh was also decided in the district court level in 1990, where the Justice Department wished to test, have blanket tests of all Justice Department attorneys, and that was held by the court at that time, the district court, to be not within the parameters announced by this court in Skinner and Von Raab.
Certiorari was sought in that case by the Government and was denied.
I consider this case to be almost exactly in line with that particular case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, the statute here, Mr. Chandler, does single out certain high-ranking State offices, and I think... I would think you're in a position... you ran for what, lieutenant governor?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You're in a position to challenge the requirement for lieutenant governor.

I don't know that you're in a position to challenge requirements for other offices which you didn't seek, and certainly, don't you think there is an argument on behalf of the State that the people have a right to have a lieutenant governor who is, free of drug use?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: First, Your Honor, the... my coplaintiff, Sharon Harris, ran for commissioner of agriculture.
Secondly, there was never any showing that drug abuse or drug use in high offices or any other offices in Georgia has been any kind of a problem.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, Georgia, then you feel can't adopt a prophylactic rule that says we want to make sure it doesn't become a problem?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: No, sir, I do not think they can.
I think that a potential problem, a hypothetical, potential problem is not a real problem and is therefore a symbolic problem.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if the Georgia statute, instead of reading the way it does, had said everybody has to take this drug test but anybody can get on the ballot.
All you have to do is announce the results of your drug test.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Your Honor, that might be more permissible in my opinion, because then it would at least leave it to the voters to decide whether they want to choose a person who submits to a test, who passes a test--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why--

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --or who refuses a test.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I thought you were complaining about the search.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The search would be exactly the same in that situation, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So how would it be any better?
I mean, if your real objection is the search, your answer should be, you know, no, it's just as bad.
I think he's capable of answering himself.
Well, but he's not capable, perhaps, of perceiving whether what he's objecting to is the search, Chief Justice.
If... maybe you're not objecting to the search, then.
You have some other problem than the search?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I certainly object to the search as a prerequisite to being... to ballot placement, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, isn't there a search in this other case?
But you don't object to that.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: In which other case?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: In the case the Chief Justice put to you, where you had to undergo the same search, but you could run whether it came out positive or negative.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Well, I'm just saying that there's... that that would not... I think it's for the people of Georgia to decide whether or not you can be on the ballot, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'm sorry, I just don't understand, given that your objection is to the search--

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --why you would not... if it is to the search.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Maybe it's not.
I don't understand why you would not find the Chief Justice's hypothetical just as bad as the one that you confront.
You can't run unless you get searched.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Well, obviously, Your Honor, I have objected to the search.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Or take another example.
No testing before, but the moment you are elected to office, you must have a test and you must repeat it annually.
Would you object to that?
Then the voters make their choice without any requirement of a--

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I would object to that because, Justice Ginsburg, there's no showing that there is a problem.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Well then, how does that differ from in between the time that you're on the ballot and the time that you're elected?
What is the difference in my situation, in the question that I pose and the one that Justice Scalia posed?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I believe this Court has held, at least since the Carroll case in 1925, that blanket searches are intolerable, and that that would just be a blanket search.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And would that be the same if every employee was required to get a physical examination once a year?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Yes, sir, I believe it would be.

It would be a blanket search required by government, and I think a blanket search of people to determine whether or not they're using drugs, or whether or not they have a terminal illness, or whether or not they have a genetic defect, or a blood-borne disease... we have to look at--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And that's because you object to the intrusion of going into the doctor's office, not the disclosure of the result?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Insofar as that intrusion is forced upon me by the State, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Chandler, I guess the test under the Fourth Amendment is whether the search is reasonable.

Now, does it enter into the balance of whether it's reasonable at all if it were shown that the virtually universal experience of private employers is to require an annual physical of employees, or to require a periodic drug testing?
Does that affect the balance when we look at a State-ordered search or not?
Does it affect what's reasonable, the general practice in the private community?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I do not think so, Justice O'Connor, because there's a difference between the contractual relationship between employee and an employer and the political relationship between the government and candidates, and people who wish to be a part of that government.
That would be my answer to that question, Your Honor, but it may not address the point that you're concerned with.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You'd have no problem with the law saying... or maybe you do, but if a high official, say the Governor, uses drugs, he is immediately disqualified from office, illegal drugs?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: Your Honor, for one thing, that--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Would you have a problem with that?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --I would even have a problem with that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: For one thing, that presupposes that the person that's in the high office has broken the laws of the State of Georgia.
The person could have, for example, been in a jurisdiction or another country where such drug use was not even illegal.
Therefore, he would not have broken the laws under the State of Georgia.
It is a shifting majority decides what is legal and illegal.
We see tobacco, for example, approaching illegality in this country, or portions thereof.
That introduces the novel idea that a citizen of a State is subject to the jurisdiction of that State no matter where in the world he or she might go, and that is an element--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You think drug use is irrelevant to the abilities and the qualifications of a public officeholder?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Your Honor, I would think that that would be a matter of a question of how long ago was it, the frequency of use--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Let's just suppose, during his term of office.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --During his term of office, Your Honor, again it might be a question of frequency.
It might be a question of which drugs are being talked about.
It might be... there might be any number of questions--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If they're illegal drugs--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --would you distinguish between illegal drugs?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: --Your Honor, we would like always for our elected officials to be people who obey the law.

However, when the Founding Fathers set forth the Fourth Amendment's prohibitions against illegal searches, I think they realized that people would be doing things that were illegal, and the answer that they sought, the answer that they would not allow would be blanket, suspicionless searches.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But Mr. Chandler, I think the issue that's been raised is at least so far not an issue of search, as such, but an issue of substantive qualification.

Do you think there is anything unconstitutional about a State law provision to the effect that an officeholder who commits a crime... let's make it easy, a crime in the State, under State law, forfeits his office?
Is that unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: I do not think that would be unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: One of the issues here is, are there adequate protections that the people and the governments have to answer these questions?
I think there are already adequate protections in normal law enforcement, in the electoral process itself when people can be weeded out.
Nothing prevents a... an opponent of a politician in an election process to hold out his piece of paper saying he's been tested and then challenge his opponent to be tested.
Nothing would prevent that sort of buffoonery, and there's also the adequate protection of a free press and public scrutiny.
People live their whole lives, and they should be judged, perhaps, by the things that they do and the things that they say, and not by the products of their bodies.
I would like to reserve the remainder of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Chandler.
Ms. Guilday, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
This Court has established in Skinner, Von Raab, and Acton the test which permits drug testing in various contexts.
The State of Georgia is not here today to challenge that test in any way or to ask for any extensions of that test.
What we are asking the Court to do is to take the balancing of that test and apply it in a Tenth Amendment context, in the elections context.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Does Georgia think this case is moot?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Georgia thinks that the injunctive relief that Mr. Chandler and the co-petitioner sought with respect to the 1994 election is certainly moot.

The complaint also included a demand for, and the district court also recognized that the complaint also included a demand for declaratory judgment as to the merits, the constitutional merit of that statute, so to that extent, no, we do not think the case is moot.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Even in the absence of... that the petitioners would seek office in the future, and in the absence of a class action?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, we would admit that that question is close.
We read closely this Court's opinion in Storer, Norman, Meyer v. Grant, and the Democratic Party v. Wisconsin, all of which were elections cases.

There were various factual contexts in those cases, and in many, or in some at least, the facts were similar, where the electior was over and there was no statement that the particular candidates intended to run for office in the future.
Nonetheless, this Court held that because it was an elections context and the issues were likely to come before the Court again, that... I'm not sure which way to read the Court, either.
It was not moot, and so we will hear it, or it is moot, but even though it is moot we are going to consider it because it is an elections context.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I hope we didn't say that.
[Laughter]
I mean, if it is moot, how would we have Article III jurisdiction at all?
That's jurisdictional.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I believe--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: How could we say, even if it's moot we have jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --If it is not... if it is moot, the Court does not have jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You said that's what we have said.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: To be truthful, my reading of those cases makes it unclear as to what the Court was saying in each particular case.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you think it's a pleading question, Ms Guilday, that whether a case is moot or not depends on what has been pleaded, as opposed to what exists?
Suppose he pleaded that he would run again but you could demonstrate that he has no intention of running again, wouldn't the case be moot?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Your question asked whether it was a pleading--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, it seems to me it's moot if he has no intention of running again.
If he intends to run again and you accept that he... do you deny that he intends to run again?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --No, we do not.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It seems to me the case is not moot.
There is such a case where the person said he was not going to run again and this Court did hold it moot.
I forgot the name of it.
But there are other temporal things, like residency to qualify to vote, or pregnancy, that inevitably are going to be over for that particular individual.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That is correct, but in the elections context, whether this particular candidate decides to run again, certainly there will be other candidates who may make--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But he didn't ask for a class action.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --He did not.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And he has represented in Court today that he does intend to run again.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So if it's a pleading defect, it's a curable one.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Correct, and that was going to be my response to Justice Scalia's question.
If it is a pleading defect, the fact that Georgia comes in and proves that he's not going to run again, then it's no longer a pleading.
Then it's evidentiary.
So--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So how does this work?

I mean, if a case is moot, and then the parties come to this Court and they tell us something, a fact, make a factual statement that would mean it wasn't moot, are we just supposed to say, all right, now we treat the amendment as... the complaint as if it were amended?
I mean, how does this work?
I mean, there might be a lot of moot cases that people could file statements and say, well, we would like here to say a few things we didn't say in the district court which will make them not moot.
Are we now supposed to treat all these cases as if they weren't?
I mean, how does it work?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --It works, Your Honor, in fact that Mr. Chandler and the other petitioners pled in their complaint, or they requested in their complaint for declaratory relief as well as relief--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I don't see why that matters if it isn't a class action, and if there's no claim that he is going to run again.
I mean, a lot of people would like declaratory relief on a lot of theoretical questions that they have, very interesting questions of law, but--

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --This Court--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --how does this all work?
I don't think it's just enough to come in and say, I would like some declaratory relief here in the absence of a showing that you have some plaintiff to whom it makes a difference.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --This Court has responded to that very argument in the series of cases that I've just cited, which are in the elections context.
They have not required to my reading of those cases any actual allegational proof that the particular candidate who is the plaintiff in that particular case--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Isn't it a class action on behalf of other people who are clearly going to run?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --I do not believe that all of those were class actions.
I may be wrong in that, but I do not believe--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ms. Guilday, as I understand it, when this complaint was filed he didn't have to assert that he intended to run again because the election had not yet occurred.
There was clearly no mootness when the complaint was filed.
Isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --That is absolutely correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So the only issue is whether he had some obligation after the election to amend the complaint.
Now, is there some obligation?
Did the State, after the election, move to dismiss on the basis of mootness?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Because we believed that the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Did the State do that?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --No, it did not.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So why would he amend his complaint?
Did the court ask him to amend, to come forward to show that what was originally clearly not moot is now moot?
Did the court make any such request?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The district court--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I can't imagine why he would have amended his complaint, no one having raised this issue.
And Justice Scalia will correct me on this if I am mis-citing 1653, but it does say that defective allegations of jurisdiction may be amended in a trial or appellate court, so--
--Thank you for the law, Justice Ginsburg.
[Laughter]

Ms. Guilday, may I ask you whether there is any place in the record in this case where we might find evidence of some particular or special need in Georgia for a suspicionless general search program for candidates for office in Georgia?
Is there any place where, in this record, we might find that, oh, there have been a number of officeholders, State officeholders in Georgia who have turned out to have drug problems?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --There is no such record evidence in this case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Was any offered by the State and rejected?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
The reason there was not... and I'm not sure at what stage you're talking about.
At the time the legislature passed this statute, Georgia law has consistently held from the beginning that in Georgia the statute itself evidences the legislative history.
There is no recording of any committee hearings, of any floor debate, anything like that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is there any indication anywhere in this record that Georgia has a particular problem here with State officeholders being drug abusers?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: No, there is no such evidence, Your Honor, and there is no... to be frank, there is no such problem as we sit here today.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Has this Court, in dealing with suspicionless searches, looked to what special needs there might be that would be an indication that a suspicionless... a blanket, suspicionless search would be appropriate?
Isn't that what we've looked to?
Is there a special need for the government?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I think the question as to whether there is a special--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Have we looked to that, or not?
Von Raab or other cases on which you rely, has this Court looked at a special need by the government--

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --for a suspicionless search program?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Absolutely, the Court has looked at special need.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Okay.
So what is the need Georgia asserts here that is special?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The special need that Georgia asserts is that in Georgia the elected officials that are included in this statute are by constitution trustees and servants of the public.
They are, by that constitutional provision, held to a much higher standard than is the ordinary citizen.
They are, in fact, fiduciaries to the public.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Could Georgia require, instead of a physical search, an affidavit of a proposed candidate that that candidate is not now and has not been in the past a drug abuser, or user of illegal drugs?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That requirement would raise issues involving the Fifth Amendment.
Obviously, the opposite side of that is a compelled statement as to whether or not I use drugs.
Secondly, this statute does not ask the candidate to say that I use illegal drugs.
All it does is say the negative of that, that on this particular--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And you think a State could not ask a candidate to make some affidavit or certification regarding illegal drug use?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --I believe it could not.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Even if the State offers criminal immunity for making that statement?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That would then raise questions as to Federal law, would that State immunity affect any Federal drug enforcement--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is your reason for saying that the State could not require an affidavit that you had not used illegal drugs as a candidate?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --I think the question would, one, put in... it would be more intrusive and be more violative of the First Amendment rights of the individual to say, I have or have not in my past used illegal drugs.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What First Amendment right is violated there?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The compelled... the State is compelling him to make a statement which he may or may not want to make.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if the State were to require a candidate to file an affidavit saying that he had complied with the financial disclosure laws of the State, and--

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I think the State does require that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --And would that, too, be a violation of the First Amendment?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: It would not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why is one different from the other?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The difference is, this Court has upheld the validity of the financial disclosure laws in several cases.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But we've never upheld the validity of drug laws?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: You've upheld the validity of drug laws.
You have not upheld the validity of a affidavit... you have not addressed the issue, to my knowledge, of an affidavit saying I have or have not used drugs.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But why isn't the First Amendment issue, if there is one, the same in each case?
In each case perhaps a candidate is unwilling to make that statement, and yet nonetheless the State requires it of him before he goes on the ballot.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The issue in the First Amendment is, how intrusive is that of the First Amendment right?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So it's more intrusive to find out that a person has violated the drug laws than they've violated the financial disclosure laws?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The Georgia statute does not require a citizen to state that he has violated the drug law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No, but this is a hypothetical.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: As to an affidavit saying I have not violated the drug laws?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I still think that is more intrusive, because it is covering a larger period of time than is a drug test on one specific day that discloses only the presence of five specific drugs.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask in that connection whether it would be constitutional or not to require an affidavit?
At least it would not be a search, whereas I think you would agree that this test does involve a search.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: This Court has established that it is a search, so--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Now, similarly we go into the financial disclosure area and say an affidavit describing one's finances would not be a search, but do you think under the reasoning you're advancing in this case that Georgia could constitutionally require every candidate for public office to say not only what his finances are but say, you may examine all of my private papers in order to be sure I haven't committed a violation of law in the past, and you'd get a full picture of my finances.
So instead of a financial disclosure statement, we just say, you may search my papers, all of my private papers to try and find out if I've been guilty of any wrongdoing.
Would that be permissible?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --That would not be permissible.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why not, because it would probably weed out the unqualified candidates.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The test comes down again to balancing how intrusive is the nature of that infringement on First Amendment rights versus how intrusive is it in the Fourth Amendment context.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You'd rather have your papers searched than your body searched?
I don't... I'm not sure that that's... as far as intrusiveness is concerned--

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I'm not sure it's a question of which I would rather.
This Court has held in the financial disclosure area that there are limits on what those statutes can require.

They have not gotten so far... this Court and other courts have not gone so far to require a full production of income tax records, which would reveal a variety of information... you know, how many times I've gone to the doctor, how many businesses I own, or what... all of the other financial transactions I might have had.
Questions--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Well, I suppose there are Federal laws that say income tax returns are not open to examination by third parties.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --That's the point I'm making, that to compel--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But there's no Federal law, is there, saying that a State may not require a proposed candidate to make certain certifications or affidavits before being a candidate?
There's no Federal law about that, is there--

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --There's no--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --restricting the qualifications that a State may set for its elected officials?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --The same constraints that apply in this case, and that is the First Amendment, how in the elections context--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You think the First Amendment is violated by seeking... by a State requiring an affidavit of a potential candidate disclosing all criminal offenses of which the candidate has been convicted in the past?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --Perhaps we should look at the Tenth Amendment.

The Tenth Amendment says that a candidate restriction or a ballot restriction is constitutionally valid if it is a reasonable and nonarbitrarily intrusive restriction upon the individual's fundamental rights.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I wouldn't have thought you could derive all of that from the Tenth Amendment.
It doesn't say anything about ballot restrictions that I know of.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: This Court has used the Tenth Amendment to authorize the States to control their own elections, to regulate their own elections.
Of course, within those constraints--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So you take the position that a State cannot ask... make it a requirement for a candidate for State office to file an affidavit disclosing criminal offenses of which that proposed candidate has been convicted?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --No, I do not take that position because criminal--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You just did in response to my question, so what is your answer?
Can a State do that?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --My answer is--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes or no.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --Yes, if it is otherwise constitutional.
Your question--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, what other constitutional issues does that raise?
These are matters of public record.
Is it some constitutional violation to require an affidavit on some matter of public record--

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --on a proposed candidate?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: No, and that was going to be my answer.
No.
Criminal convictions are matters of public record in most States.
In some States they are not.
And so no, that would not be a restriction that impinges the Constitution in any way.

However, the financial disclosure statements, because of the privacy interest that that intrudes, yes, does touch upon constitutional issues, and at that point this Court has called... has made limits on what information can be revealed.
It's not an across-the-board, open all your papers up to the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Can you... have you finished your answer to Justice O'Connor?
Can you... can I get you back to the Fourth Amendment?
That's the part of this case that I'm most interested in, because it does raise a Fourth Amendment issue.

Do you agree that if the State required, as a condition for running for office, that the candidate must allow a representative of the State to make... or, say, a certified public accountant of his own choosing to make a thorough examination of all his financial papers, including his income tax returns... I don't think there's any Federal statute that says he can't make his income tax returns available if he wants to... that that would violate the Fourth Amendment?
Do you think it would or would not?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --I'm sorry, your hypothetical--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: My hypothetical is, the State requires not just a financial disclosure affidavit, but an opening up of the candidate's records for examination by a representative of the election commission, or whatever it is, to find out if this man may have committed some crimes or done a lot of bad things that the electorate would like to know about, such as possibly buying and selling drugs from time to time, which might be revealed by his financial records.
In order to accomplish that goal, could they require that sort of a general requirement of candidates?
Reveal your financial papers.
We don't want to trust your word that you did or did not do it.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --It comes back to the same balancing test, and that is, how invasive are those... is that restriction, or--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: They're invasive in that they reveal everything that's in writing in your private files about your correspondence with people and your financial transactions.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --I think that requirement would require the candidate to disclose much more information than would be permitted under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think it would violate... that statute would violate the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I do.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And your reason for saying, this is different, is that the search is less intrusive?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Exactly, just as this Court has held in Skinner, Von Raab, and Acton.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Because it is a body search as opposed to a paper search?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I don't think the distinction is body versus paper.
I think the distinction is what information is disclosed.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, what about a case... let's take a building search.

I suppose the State has just as much interest in assuring itself that its candidates and its officers are not drug possessors and drug dealers as it has in assuring them that they are at least not current drug users.

Would it violate the Fourth Amendment to require a candidate to open his house to a search by some private investigatory agency which would then certify after the search that no drugs were found there?
Would that violate the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I believe it certainly would violate the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And why is opening the house less intrusive than opening the body?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The difference is in the information that is disclosed.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, the information in the one case says there are no drug residues in the body, and the information in the other case is, there are no drugs in the house.
Why is there a significant distinction between those two disclosures?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: There's two distinctions.
In the Georgia statute, yes, we require the candidate to submit the urine sample.
The information comes back only to him.
That is, whether or not there are--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And he then has to pass it on... and I guess I was assuming... maybe I didn't state it carefully enough, but I was assuming that in my example he would have to pass on the certification from the private investigatory agency.
In each case the candidate could withhold the certification and be disqualified.
Assuming that, is there any distinction in principle or practice between the degree of intrusion?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --The private investigatory agency has learned a substantial amount of information.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, so does the laboratory or the tester in the case of the bodily search.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The tester learns only the presence of those five drugs.
Any other individual that walks into a candidate's home or to my home learns everything about me, and I think that's the distinction, the amount of information that's disclosed by the required test.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or the amount of what is searched also.
Isn't that relevant also?

I mean, wouldn't your answer be different if the test in question, even though it only came up with those five drugs, is a test that required a full body search, body cavity search and everything else.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That's absolutely true.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Your point here is this is just a urinalysis.
That's all that's involved.
How does this test work, actually?
Like... I don't see how... I'm not totally familiar with how the statute works.
It sounds as if it tells a candidate, well, in some 30-day period of your choosing go in and get a drug test.
Is that what it does?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Not within some 30 days of your choosing, 30 days within the qualifying deadlines for the particular office that you were running for.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is it a deadline, or is it when he files?
I mean, it's usually... say the deadline's September 30.
Suppose he files the preceding June 30.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: No.
This statute says--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It has to be... in other words, the deadline's September 30.
It has to be in the month of September.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --The particular offices that are involved in the statute have particular times for qualifying.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So you have to be 30 days previous to that.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You find one day where you go in and you're drug-free.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, so how's that supposed to prove anything?
I mean, I guess the greatest druggie in the world could go in and find a day when he was drug-free.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: As this Court held in Von Raab, perhaps the greatest druggie in the world could not.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is that right?
That's what I don't know.
I mean, how... what are the facts?
That is, if a person does take drugs, is it impossible to find a day in a 30-day period when he's free of drugs and would pass the test?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That, of course--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Suppose he stays off drugs for a month preceding, or 2 months preceding the test.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --If that particular individual can do that, yes, you're right, when he goes in for his drug test, his drug test is going to become positive--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: How long in advance of the test do you have to stay off drugs if a moderate drug user, before the moderate drug user is drug-free on the day of the test?
Is 3 weeks good enough?
Is 4 weeks good enough?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --The cases before this Court have cited expert testimony giving a range of from 22 days until a month before.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
So I mean, what is the statute doing?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: It's doing--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is it simply... what is the theory behind the statute other than making a political statement?
Is it that there are some people who want to run for office who find it impossible to refrain from drugs for 22 days prior to their voluntarily going in and taking the test?
I mean, what is the theory of the statute?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --I think that is one purpose, to--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is that an important purpose, a purpose that we find those people in society who are not able to stay off drugs for 22 days and therefore... is that the basic idea?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --That is not the primary reason, no.
It is a reason that this Court in Von Raab found to be significant.
In our case, the primary purpose we would offer this Court for this statute is that the information that a negative drug test gives to the public about the individual candidate is significant.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Has this Court ever gone into the... I mean, I thought in Vernonia, for example they're like random drug-testing.
Random drug-testing, of course, catches people.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Have there been cases which are not random drug-testing?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: Von Raab involved pre-employment or pre-promotion testing, one-time basis, of individuals who sought positions in the various categories.
It was not random testing.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Guilday, do I understand you correctly that your major reason, Georgia's major reason is symbolic to the extent I think you said they wanted the public... they wanted the people who were in public office to have what it takes to exercise their best judgment.
Is that--

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: That is our purpose.
It is not our position that that is a solely symbolic purpose.
It may have symbolic implications, but because a statute is symbolic, if it's otherwise constitutional, does not render it constitutional.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --This is my question, then.

If it comes down to, this is not like the random test that's designed to catch people but is in part symbolic, and the State is making a judgment, and then we have a Constitution with the Fourth Amendment in it, if we're choosing between the public perception, the lesson that we want to teach the people, doesn't the constitutional amendment come first, come before the notion that we want people to show that they can exercise their best judgment by being willing to submit to drug testing?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: My way of answering that question is what I started saying in the beginning.
The Fourth Amendment requires the balancing test that this Court used in Skinner, Von Raab, and Acton to determine whether or not a particular--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But my question to you is, then, doesn't the Fourth Amendment always win on that balance unless you have a good reason, a reason beyond, we want to show that these people take tests.
One reason is that you would catch people, as was the case in the train engineer, but here that's not the purpose.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --The Fourth Amendment always wins out if in that balancing test the government interests are not sufficient to outweigh the privacy interest.
It is our position that when you do that test in an elections context in which the people have a right to know anything about a candidate which touches on their qualifications for office--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Then go for... once they're in office, and they're going to be in and maybe run for election, so do this periodically?
Can people have any less... is their interest any less if we're doing this balancing?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --No, the balancing is no less in that context.
The distinction or the reason for not requiring them then primarily are procedural.
Once--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you could... as a matter of constitutional law, Georgia could say, annually, or even randomly, everyone in office in this State has to have a drug test.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --Everyone in the category of offices that are included in the statute, yes, I believe Georgia could have--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if you rely on the public's right to know everything about the candidate, as I think you described it, it seems to me that that would justify a totally unrestricted search of the house and all private papers.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --I said that and I... and that is a quote from one of this Court's cases.
However, obviously the Constitution has to define everything.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And the Constitution looks a little more closely at totally suspicionless searches, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: It does.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

I take it... or I took it that part of your argument for the State interest that sort of overcomes the private interest here is based on the Tenth Amendment, and I'm not sure that I understand that argument.
I mean, I take it you do not argue that the Tenth Amendment in effect gives the State some kind of right or some dispensation from the Fourth Amendment, so what is the Tenth Amendment argument?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: The Tenth Amendment argument is, in this balancing test that's required in the Fourth Amendment, that in the usual context the scales start out even for both sides.
What the Tenth Amendment does is, it tips those scales from the outset on the side of the government because--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --Because the Tenth Amendment in the cases this Court has held in the elections context say, we are going to give great deference to the State's own characterizations of its interest in the elections and in particular in the qualifications of its elected officials.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, there's no question of there being an assertable Tenth Amendment interest there, but there's no question about there being an assertable Tenth Amendment interest to prosecute homicide, but that doesn't affect the balancing that goes on in determining... or that does not affect the Fourth Amendment analysis.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: I'm not sure I understand--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, I suppose if someone challenged the right of the State to prosecute murder we would say, well, that certainly is not one of those powers that was taken away from the State when the national Constitution was ratified.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --That's absolutely--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I don't see how that would affect the Fourth Amendment analysis when somebody objected to an unreasonable search and seizure that had resulted in evidence that the State wanted to introduce in a homicide case.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --The distinction being that the Tenth Amendment and in particular the elections context has repeatedly been given by this Court special consideration.
In Gregory--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, we've said that a great deal of discretion over elections is within the State's power, but that's as far as we've gone, isn't it?
Thank you, Ms. Guilday.

turn.speaker: patricia_guilday
turn.label: Ms. Patricia Guilday
turn.text: --Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Chandler, you have 5 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: An interesting aspect of the Tenth Amendment question to me is that that the States... that which was not granted to the Federal Government specifically was... the rights not granted to the Federal Government was reserved to the States or the people respectively, and when the States appear to jealously protect their rights, they are not so jealous in protecting the rights that the people reserved unto themselves, and one of those rights is that a citizen should be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr Chandler, do you think this case would be stronger for the State if it was random drug-testing?
Does that thought comfort you, if they amended this statute to make it random?

turn.speaker: walker_l_chandler
turn.label: Mr. Walker L. Chandler
turn.text: It would not comfort me, Your Honor, and I'm not sure--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: This is stronger, isn't it, because it says... basically what she said was that this is the State's interest only in making certain that the really serious drug users who can't stay off drugs for 30 days, which you have to be quite a heavy user, that they want to identify those people, so she said that's a very important interest, identifying these very, very heavy drug users, and against that it's a fairly limited intrusion.
I think that was her point.
